name: Service Cloud
description: Salesforce's customer service and support platform
justification: Service Cloud is a core Salesforce product for customer service organizations. Analyzing its actual usage provides insights into how effectively an organization has implemented support operations in Salesforce.

indicators.description: Primary objects that form the foundation of Service Cloud
indicators.justification: These objects represent the fundamental building blocks of Service Cloud. Their presence, customization, and active use are the strongest indicators of Service Cloud adoption.

items.name: Case
items.description: Primary object for tracking customer issues and requests
items.justification: The Case object is the central component of Service Cloud. It's virtually impossible to use Service Cloud without utilizing Cases. High weight (0.9) reflects this critical importance.

items.name: Contact
items.description: Customer contact information linked to cases
items.justification: While Contacts are part of the standard CRM, they play an important role in Service Cloud for customer identification. Medium weight (0.5) acknowledges their importance but recognizes they're not exclusive to Service Cloud.

items.name: CaseComment
items.description: Comments on case resolution and updates
items.justification: Case Comments indicate active case collaboration. High weight (0.7) reflects that organizations actively using Service Cloud typically have significant case comment activity.

items.name: Solution
items.description: Standard solutions to common problems (legacy)
items.justification: Solutions are an older Service Cloud feature. Medium-high weight (0.6) indicates their relevance while acknowledging many organizations now use Knowledge instead.

indicators.description: Evidence of knowledge base usage for support
indicators.justification: Knowledge management is a key differentiator of Service Cloud implementations. Organizations with mature service operations typically invest heavily in knowledge management.

items.name: Knowledge__kav
items.description: Knowledge articles for self-service and agent assistance
items.justification: Knowledge articles represent a significant investment in service quality. High weight (0.8) reflects both the importance of knowledge in Service Cloud and the effort required to implement it.

items.name: Knowledge Settings
items.description: Knowledge base configuration indicating investment in agent knowledge
items.justification: Configured knowledge settings indicate commitment to knowledge-centered support. High weight (0.7) as this represents intentional implementation rather than incidental usage.

items.name: Article Types
items.description: Custom article types indicate structured knowledge management
items.justification: Custom article types show sophisticated knowledge management. High weight (0.8) as this indicates significant investment in content strategy.

items.name: Knowledge Usage
items.description: Evidence of agents viewing and using knowledge articles
items.justification: Knowledge usage shows actual adoption by service agents. High weight (0.7) as it demonstrates real-world value beyond just configuration.

indicators.description: Evidence of Service Console usage for agent productivity
indicators.justification: The Service Console provides the primary interface for agent productivity in Service Cloud. Its presence and customization strongly indicate Service Cloud investment.

items.name: Service Console App
items.description: Dedicated console application for service agents
items.justification: A dedicated Service Console app is central to agent efficiency. High weight (0.8) reflects its importance to service operations.

items.name: Console Customizations
items.description: Custom console components and utilities
items.justification: Console customizations indicate investment in agent experience. High weight (0.7) as it shows commitment to optimizing service workflows.

items.name: Console Usage
items.description: Evidence of agents actively using the Service Console
items.justification: Actual console usage is the strongest indicator of Service Cloud adoption. Very high weight (0.9) as it directly measures active utilization.

items.name: Quick Text
items.description: Pre-defined text snippets for consistent agent responses
items.justification: Quick Text indicates investment in efficiency and consistency. Medium-high weight (0.6) as it's a valuable but not essential Service Cloud feature.

items.name: Macros
items.description: Automated agent workflows for common tasks
items.justification: Macros show investment in agent efficiency. High weight (0.7) as they represent significant effort to streamline service processes.

indicators.justification: Self-service capabilities are increasingly central to modern Service Cloud implementations, reducing case volume and improving customer satisfaction.

items.name: Experience Cloud for Service
items.description: Customer self-service portal or community
items.justification: Service communities represent significant investment in self-service. High weight (0.8) as they indicate strategic commitment to digital service channels.

items.name: Web-to-Case
items.description: Online case submission form for customers
items.justification: Web-to-Case indicates digital service channel investment. High weight (0.7) as it's a common and important Service Cloud implementation.

items.name: Email-to-Case
items.description: Email integration for case creation
items.justification: Email-to-Case shows integration of email channels with service processes. High weight (0.7) as it's a fundamental service integration.

items.name: EmailMessage
items.description: Email messages related to cases
items.justification: EmailMessage records indicate active email channel usage. Medium-high weight (0.6) shows importance of email for service communications.

items.name: Chat for Service
items.description: Live chat capabilities for customer support
items.justification: Chat implementation shows investment in real-time service channels. High weight (0.7) as it represents significant channel expansion.

indicators.justification: Service automation indicates process maturity and efficiency focus, typically seen in more sophisticated Service Cloud implementations.

items.name: Case Assignment Rules
items.description: Automated case routing to appropriate agents or queues
items.justification: Assignment rules indicate structured service processes. High weight (0.8) as they're fundamental to efficient case handling.

items.name: Auto-Response Rules
items.description: Automated customer notifications when cases are created
items.justification: Auto-response rules show attention to customer communication. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they enhance the customer experience.

items.name: Escalation Rules
items.description: Time-based rules to escalate unresolved cases
items.justification: Escalation rules indicate sophisticated case management. High weight (0.7) as they show commitment to service level adherence.

items.name: Case Queues
items.description: Shared queues for case assignment to teams
items.justification: Case queues indicate team-based support structure. High weight (0.7) as they're central to most service operations.

items.name: Case Record Types
items.description: Different case types for varied support processes
items.justification: Case record types show process differentiation by issue type. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they indicate process sophistication.

indicators.justification: Entitlement and SLA tracking indicate advanced service operations with formalized service commitments, typically found in mature Service Cloud implementations.

items.name: Entitlement
items.description: Entitlements for tracking customer service agreements
items.justification: Entitlements indicate formalized service contracts. High weight (0.7) as they represent sophisticated service delivery.

items.name: ServiceContract
items.description: Service contracts for customers
items.justification: Service contracts show formalized customer service relationships. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they indicate advanced service operations.

items.name: Entitlement Processes
items.description: Processes for enforcing SLAs on cases
items.justification: Entitlement processes show sophisticated SLA enforcement. High weight (0.8) as they represent significant implementation effort.

items.name: Milestone Tracking
items.description: Tracking of service milestones for cases
items.justification: Milestone tracking indicates detailed SLA management. High weight (0.7) as it shows sophisticated service timing enforcement.

indicators.description: Evidence of field service management capabilities
indicators.justification: Field Service indicators show extension of service operations to on-site work, representing an expanded Service Cloud implementation.

items.name: WorkOrder
items.description: Work orders for field service operations
items.justification: Work orders are the central object for Field Service. High weight (0.8) as they directly indicate Field Service adoption.

items.name: ServiceAppointment
items.description: Appointments for field service visits
items.justification: Service appointments represent scheduled field work. High weight (0.7) as they're core to field service operations.

items.name: ServiceResource
items.description: Resources that can be assigned to field service work
items.justification: Service resources indicate technician management. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they show field workforce configuration.

items.name: Field Service Settings
items.description: Configuration of Field Service Lightning
items.justification: Field Service settings indicate intentional FSL implementation. High weight (0.8) as they show deliberate enablement.

indicators.description: Evidence of active usage by service agents
indicators.justification: User activity provides direct evidence of actual Service Cloud adoption, beyond mere configuration. These behavioral indicators are highly weighted as they demonstrate value realization.

items.name: Case Views
items.description: Evidence of agents working cases
items.justification: Case views directly indicate agent engagement with Service Cloud. Very high weight (0.9) as this is the clearest signal of active usage.

items.name: Case List Views
items.description: Evidence of agents monitoring case queues
items.justification: Case list view activity shows queue management. High weight (0.7) as it indicates active case workload handling.

items.name: Service Dashboards
items.description: Evidence of service performance monitoring
items.justification: Service dashboard usage indicates data-driven management. Medium-high weight (0.6) as it shows analytical approach to service operations.

items.name: Service Reports
items.description: Evidence of service analytics usage
items.justification: Service reports usage indicates performance analysis. Medium-high weight (0.6) as it demonstrates management oversight.

indicators.description: Evidence of Service Cloud being integrated with other systems
indicators.justification: Integrations indicate that Service Cloud has been embedded into the broader service technology ecosystem, showing strategic commitment.

items.name: CTI Integration
items.description: Phone system integration for service operations
items.justification: CTI integration is critical for contact center operations. High weight (0.8) as it represents significant service infrastructure investment.

items.name: Social Customer Service
items.description: Integration with social media for service
items.justification: Social channel integration shows omni-channel service approach. High weight (0.7) as it represents channel expansion.

items.name: Case API Calls
items.description: API integration with Case object indicates programmatic service operations
items.justification: Case API usage indicates integration with other systems. High weight (0.7) as it shows service process automation.

indicators.description: Evidence of custom code interacting with Service Cloud
indicators.justification: Custom code development represents significant investment in tailoring Service Cloud to specific business needs, indicating deep commitment.

items.name: Case Triggers
items.description: Custom Apex on cases indicates advanced service automation
items.justification: Case triggers indicate sophisticated process customization. High weight (0.7) as they represent significant development investment.

items.name: Knowledge Triggers
items.description: Custom Apex for knowledge management
items.justification: Knowledge triggers show customized knowledge processes. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they indicate tailored knowledge management.

items.name: Service Cloud Lightning Components
items.description: Custom UI components for Service Cloud indicates deep customization
items.justification: Custom Service Cloud components show UI investment. Medium-high weight (0.6) as they indicate tailored agent experiences.

editionJustification: Edition detection is based on feature availability and usage patterns. Features are mapped to the editions where they first become available, with more advanced features appearing in higher editions. This helps identify both the currently licensed edition and potential upgrade paths.

coreObjects.Case: Case management is in active use
coreObjects.Solution: Solutions are being used for knowledge sharing
coreObjects.EmailMessage: Email communication is integrated with case management
coreObjects.WorkOrder: Field service work orders are being utilized
coreObjects.ServiceAppointment: Field service appointments are being scheduled

features.Service Console App: Service Console is configured for agent productivity
features.Email-to-Case: Email-to-Case is configured for customer communications
features.Web-to-Case: Web-to-Case is enabled for online customer requests
features.Case Queues: Team-based case queues are in use
features.Entitlement Processes: Service level agreement processes are configured
features.Quick Text: Quick Text is configured for consistent responses
features.Macros: Macros are configured for agent efficiency
features.Chat for Service: Live chat is implemented for real-time support

findingsJustification: Findings are mapped directly to detected evidence points, translating technical detection into business-meaningful insights. Each finding is phrased to be actionable and understandable by non-technical stakeholders.
